Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story: I was sitting at my desk, half-listening to the hum of my laptop as I scrolled through bug reports. Another message popped up from QA about the same minor UI glitch—nothing critical, just a button that sometimes shifted out of place. I knew the workaround, and so did the users, but the expectation was clear: fix it, make it perfect. My phone buzzed. It was my stepdad, asking if I had a minute to talk. Lately, he and Mom seemed distant, and I’d promised myself I’d check in more, be the supportive step-child they needed. I glanced at the clock. If I called now, I’d lose my focus and probably miss the window to push the fix before the end of the day. But if I waited, I’d be letting them down, again. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my team counting on me to keep things running smoothly, my family hoping I’d be there when they reached out. I stared at the phone, torn, feeling the familiar ache of being pulled in two directions at once.
